results.title: We're not married!
results.creator_credit: Nunnally Johnson, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Edmund Goulding
results.brief_description: One Christmas a couple eager to earn a spot on the radio show, ‘Breakfast with the glad Gladwyns’ (the couple must be married to be believable), rush to get married by a newly appointed marriage celebrant. 2 years and 6 months later, the couple are rich, radio stars, but still bickering and unhappy and are delighted when they receive a letter in the mail saying they are not legally married. It appears that 6 couples married by the celebrant were not legal as he began practicing before his legal appointment. Thus, the couples are given a second chance at deciding whether or not they’re happy with the partner they’ve chosen and their life together so far. Couples contemplating their future include the unhappy radio performers (Ginger Rogers and Fred Allen), an aspiring Mrs America and her house husband (Marilyn Monroe and David Wayne), a philanderer and his wife who have run out of things to say (Eve Arden and Paul Douglas), a gold digger already beginning divorce proceedings (Zsa Zsa Gabor and Louis Calhern), and a soldier and his pregnant wife desperate to make their first born child legitimate (Mitzi Gaynor and Eddie Bracken). The 6th couple have already divorced. Features the original theatrical trailer.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Nunnally Johnson, Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and Edmund Goulding

results.title: We're no angels
results.creator_credit: Pat Duggan, Paramount Pictures and Michael Curtiz
results.brief_description: Set in French Guiana, three convicts escape from the notorious prison on Devil’s Island and hide amongst the colonists. In need of clothing and money, the three make plans to rob a milliner, Felix, and his family. The trio are deterred from their larcenous intents when they develop a fondness for the family. Discovering that Felix is on the verge of bankruptcy, the convicts offer their services as household help. Matters are further complicated when they discover that Felix’s wealthy cousin arrives to audit the books. Cast includes: Humphrey Bogart, Aldo Ray, Peter Ustinov, Joan Bennett and Basil Rathbone.

results.title: We're here to stay
results.creator_credit: Ian McLaren and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “West”.
That is the resolve of Agri-Pool, seven farm families in Lestock, Saskatchewan, who have pooled their resources so that rising operating costs will not drive them off their land. By pooling their land, their equipment, their livestock, and farming as a cooperative, they are able to live as they choose, to maintain their standard of living, and even to have some spare time left over to enjoy. This is an engaging look at a novel approach to big-scale farming.

results.title: We're here now : prostitution
results.brief_description: This program focuses on the myths and realities of prostitution as revealed by seven former prostitutes. These women are struggling to return to the mainstream of society and they meet in a group counselling session that offers mutual support and guidance. This film does not record “street life”. Instead, it shows women coming to grips with the great problems of their lives. It also demonstrates the powerful dynamics of group therapy and the therapeutic value of self-help organisations.

results.title: We're gonna have recess (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: William Canning, ONF | NFB and Michael Scott
results.brief_description: To smile at the antics of children in a playground is to smile at oneself. This is a candid camera view of the schoolyard during recess, when hearts are broken, scores settled, secrets told, and where a bouncing ball or a turning rope can still tell the future to a chanted rhyme. Filmed without commentary, this is a small world and a brief one, but a world of childhood that everyone will recognize. Film without words.

results.title: Wayward girls & wicked women. - Volume 3.
results.brief_description: This is the final part of a three volume series featuring the best of world animation by women. The three films included have been recognised for their ground breaking qualities and make witty and provocative use of the myths, fairytales, and sexual iconography that have affected the way women have been seen - and see themselves. Featuring: Asparagus/Susan Pitt; The Decision/Vera Neubauer; The Brooch Pin and the Sinful Clasp/Joanna Woodward.

results.title: Wayward girls & wicked women. - Volume 2.
results.brief_description: Unlike the world of live action feature films, animation is a form of filmmaking in which women, particularly over the last two decades, have made an enormous impact. This second part of the series aims to give a taste of the range of voices and styles in contemporary animation. Some of the films are intensely personal, some give new, relevant life to the phrase “the personal is the political”, some re-invent the comic cartoon but all are truly original pieces of animation. Titles include: Fatty Issues/Candy Guard; The Door/Nina Shorina; The Stain/Marjut Rimminen & Christine Roche; Delivery Man/Emily Hubley; Daddy’s Little Bit of Dresden China/Karen Watson; You Be Mother/Sarah Pucill; Wishful Thinking/Candy Guard; Greek Tragedy/Nicole van Goethem; The Interview/Caroline Leaf & Veronica Soul; Girls’ Night Out/Joanna Quinn.

results.title: Wayward girls & wicked women. - Volume 1.
results.brief_description: Unlike the world of live action feature films, animation is a form of filmmaking in which women, particularly over the last two decades, have made an enormous impact. This first in a series aims to give a taste of the range of voices and styles in contemporary animation. Some of the films are intensely personal, some reinvent the comic cartoon but all are truly original pieces of animation. Titles include: Feet of song/Erica Russell; Two sisters/Caroline Leaf; Alternative fringe/Candy Guard; Springfield/Emma Calder; Emergence of Eunice/Emily Hubley; Poodle/Nina Shorina; A little something/Candy Guard; Murders most foul/Gillian Lacey; Some protection/Marjut Rimminen; Full of grace/Nicole Van Goethem; Second class mail/Alison Snowden.
